Q12. Is there any change to the time limit of completing the QP module examinations and final examination?
Ans
The policy on completion requirements, that candidates need to pass an individual module within four attempts or within five years and a pass in the final examination within four attempts or within three years, has been removed.
However, the overall time limit to complete QP remains the same. That is, the four modules and final examination must be completed within 10 years from the date of registration as a student with the Institute.

It depends on whether the company is engaging in money lending business or just simply lend a loan to its employee.

S 15(1)(f) and (g) deems interest received by a person, a corporation or F.I. taxable if it is sourced in HK.

If it is a money lending business, the operation test applied and whether or not interest is taxable depends on what the recipient has done and where he has done to earn it.

If it is a simply lend of money, the provision of credit test applies and whether or not interest is taxable depends on where money is first made to the borrower.

Also, whether the interest paid by the employee is taxable or not does not affect whether or not interest received by the company is taxable. This is because nothing in the case laws and the IRO state this.

As for interest expenses paid by the employee, it can be deductible if it was made for the purpose of a home loan (as in salaries tax) or if PA was elected, the mortgage loan interest.

If the company lends money not to employee but someone carrying in business, then this person is subject to profits tax, and for interest to be deductible the following tests have to be passed:
1. S 16(1),
2. S16(2)(a) to S 16(2)(f), and
3. S 16(2A) to S 16(2C).
